3025.text:
I can't do it in aero position like some people
do it.

3028.text: I hold on for dear life.

3032.text: I think it's like anything else.

3034.text:
You have to kind of think back to being a
kid.

3038.text:
And kids try everything, try anything, fall
down, get back up, do it again because they're

3044.text: So you have to try to lock that out.

3047.text:
Bring back that child inside you and say,
"granted you have to keep in mind the risk

3054.text:
I know a guy who's a phenomenal cyclist but
after he's married and has kids, he's on the

3058.text:
brakes that whole time and he used to just
fly down.

3063.text: You have to keep it realistic for yourself.

3066.text: Find that inner kid in you.

3070.text:
If this happened when I was 12, once the cast
is off, I'm back out there.

3074.text: So same kind of thing we have to do.

3076.text:
As we get older, recovery time is what we
don't have.

3079.text: That's why I don't try snow board.

3081.text:
I remember trying to snow board and I fell
like six times.

3084.text: The next day I was like I can't move.

3087.text: I just learned how to ski.

3090.text: As you get older, you can't recover as fast.

3094.text:
Find that inner child in you get rid of that
fear.

3099.text:
>> Female #2: I'm wondering how you view yourself
now versus how you thoughtful yourself before

3108.text:
You know, we all have a pretty good sense
of ourselves.

3112.text:
And then, when something like that happens,
your spirit's broken and you know, that's

3116.text: why you went through that phase.

3119.text:
And some of the things that define us before
something like that happens and they're taken

3124.text:
away from us causes us to think differently
of ourselves afterwards.

3127.text: How do you view yourself now?

3130.text:
>>Matt: As Mr. Murphy said, I have a little
bit of an ego.

3136.text:
[laughter] I was always a confident person
before the accident.

3141.text:
That 2-year journey where it was kind of sucked
out of me, I guess, without sounding too cocky,

3150.text:
you know, I realize that I'm tough son of
a bitch.

3159.text: I got that from my parents.

3161.text:
I was put through an awful lot and I wouldn't
want my worst enemy to go through what I went

3171.text:
But I know for a fact now that you don't do
things by yourself.

3176.text:
You know, if it wasn't for my mom and dad,
my brothers and sisters my fire department

3180.text:
friends and family, Vicky, Frank, and Noel,
the triathlete group that I trained with,

3186.text:
if it wasn't for that support group, I'm a
huge country fan.

3189.text:
Kenny Chesney has a song, I didn't get here
alone.

3193.text: I didn't get to this point alone.

3196.text:
I know that now more than ever that I relied
on those people and those friendships to get

3201.text:
And to make this recovery and this comeback
possible.

3204.text: But I'm still tough son of a bitch.

3210.text:
[chuckles] Well, Matt, your story has been
tremendously inspirational to me personally

3216.text:
and to a lot of the folks here at the Google
New York City office.

3220.text:
I know this was a busy week for you with the
New York City marathon being Sunday.

3223.text:
So for you to take some time out of your schedule,
we really appreciate it.

3227.text: Thanks so much for coming back.
